_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Policy:
The City of San Diego Water Department has and continues to design facilities, operate and maintain equipment and commit the personnel and resources to meet or exceed industry standards and regulatory requirements.  The City developed and implemented the City's Process Safety Management/ Risk Management Prevention Program that provides a systematic approach to employee involvement, safety awareness and program assessment.

Plant Description:
The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant was built in the early 1950's and became an architecture center piece of the community due to its beauty and mission style design. The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant has a maximum water treatment capacity of 150-million gallons per day (mgd), with a current capital improvement project goal of expanding treated water capacity to 200 mgd. The facility is located on a mesa on relatively flat terrain bounded by the Lake Murray Reservoir to the north, and by residential areas in other directions bordering the City of La Mesa.  There is elevated terrain across the reservoir, and downward-sloping terrain to the south.

Alvarado Water Treatment Plant uses a combined form of chlorine to disinfect water, making it suitable for use in the City of San Diego's drinking water distribution system and for sale to other agencies. The chlorine is received in one-ton pressurized liquid cylinders at the Chlorine Storage Room in the Raw Water Chemical Building.

Commitment:
The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant has a well trained and committed operations and maintenance staff with a record of over 50 years of using chlorine safely.  To support the efforts of continued safe handling and use of chlorine at the Alvarado Water Treatment Plant, senior management has committed to the development of a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program under the guidelines of State and Federal mandates which has involved complete engineering reviews of the chlorine feed system and design certification.

The combination of the passive (e.g. building) and the active treatments reduce the endpoints to less than 100 feet which is well within the facility's property.

Safety Elements:
Safety elements include administrative controls, engineering controls and personal protective equipment (PPE).  

Administrative elements may include but are not limited to:
- Standard operations
- Maintenance procedures
- Training
- Record Keeping

Engineering controls may include but are not limited to:
- Facility alarms
- Isolation Valves
- Chlorine Scrubbers

PPE controls may include but are not limited to:
- Self Contained Breathing Apparatus 
- Chemical Protective Overalls
- Safety Goggles

The Risk Management Prevention and Process Safety Management Programs have been developed and implemented.  The Risk Management Prevention is in fulfillment of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR PART 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions and the California Code of Regulations Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 - California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The Process Safety Management Program is in fulfillment of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's (OSHA) 1910.119, as well as Cal/OSHA's California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials.
 
As with the use of any hazardous chemicals, the use of chlorine in this treatment process poses the potential for an accidental release that could have offsite consequences.  It is for this reason that several years ago, under the provisions of 40 CFR PART 68, the Alvarado Water Treatment Plant conducted an assessment of offsite consequences of accident scenarios involving the uncontrolled release of chlorine to the surrounding environment.  Under the provisions of the rule, the treatment process used at the Alvarado Water Treatment Plant is considered a Program 3 process, and as such conducted an analysis of: (1) a worstÂ¬case release scenario and (2) one or more alternative release scenarios. The analysis of offsite consequences produced information incorporated into the Risk Management Plan (RMP) which covers population and environmental receptors in the environs within the affected areas.

4)	The chlorine storage room was constructed as a containment facility to eliminate the free discharge of chlorine to the atmosphere. A critical component of this system is the scrubber, which is capable, in the event of a release, of neutralizing 2,000 pounds of chlorine. This scrubber is activated by data acquired by the leak sensors, and may be initiated manually by Plant staff;

Emergency Response:
The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant, in conjunction with the Water Department Emergency Management Coordinator, have developed and tested a Chlorine Emergency Response Plan. The Emergency Response Plan was developed to support the Water Plant Operator in the event a chlorine release occurs and additional resources are needed to mitigate the situation. The San Diego Fire Department, Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team is dedicated to respond to our water plants if we have an incident. The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant has a Business Plan that identifies evacuation points on the site and provides additional emergency information about chlorine and additional contacts if needed.
 
The Chlorine Emergency Response Plan describes in detail the procedures for responding to a chlorine release or chlorine release threat.  The Plan contains a flow chart which visually presents this information for both controlled and uncontrolled release scenarios.  The basic emergency response steps include:
- Verification/Situation Assessment
- Isolation
- Notification
- Reporting
- Remediation & Recovery
- Incident Investigation
- Implementation of Improvements
- Training

Additionally, upgraded security systems were added to all access points to allow the duty operator to monitor the complete facility with ease.

Accident History:
The City has maintained a clean record of accidental releases of acutely hazardous materials with as of January 28, 2010, no significant accidental releases of chlorine occurring within the last five years requiring plant evacuation or requiring off site evacuation or consequences.
 
Compliance Audit:
The most recent compliance audit was conducted in accordance with RMP/PSM requirements by an outside consultant in 2010.  The audit was to evaluate the adequacy of the PSM and RMP programs and provide recommendations of improvements.
